ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The Sunrise Growers facility located in Santa Maria, California, utilizes refrigeration for the cold and freezer storage of a wide variety of fruits and vegetables.



Senior management at Sunrise Growers is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  Senior management as well as Human Resources administer the facility's safety and environmental policies and programs.  These programs include but are not limited to forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturers' documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.



Sunrise Growers has coordinated emergency response efforts with the local fire department, the Santa Barbara County Fire Department.  In the case of an ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of Sunrise Growers to evacuate the employees and to allow the fire department/HazMat team to respond to the emergency.  The refrigeration contractor will be available for guidance and assistance.



The majority of the equipment is located inside the engine rooms.  The system is a closed loop refrigeration system similar to a residential refrigerator.  There are no emissions or planned releases of ammonia.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The facility is located in a rural area at 1315 South Blosser Road, in Santa Maria, California, which is approximately 2.0 miles east of Highway 101, and approximately 0.2 miles south of Highway 166.  The facility began operations in 1956 and expanded in 1980.  The facility provides refrigeration for cold and freezer storage of fruits and vegetables.  At the time of construction and facility expansion, the ammonia system was constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulation

s including the Uniform Fire and Mechanical Codes.



The facility has one ammonia refrigeration system onsite, which acts as two separate systems. The two systems are connected via one ammonia liquid and one ammonia suction line.  Unless the facility is transferring liquid from system 1 to system 2, the connection lines are normally closed. The total charge of the ammonia systems combined was calculated by Appco in 2012 and found to be 42,098 pounds of ammonia.



System 1's refrigeration cycle begins with the collection of high pressure liquid ammonia in the High Pressure Receivers (3) from the Condensers.  The High Pressure Receivers serve as the main liquid storage vessels for system 1.  The High Pressure Receivers provide high pressure liquid ammonia to the Pre-cool Pump Package, Belt Freezer (IQF #9), Poly Bag Room Evaporators, and Intercooler.  The High Pressure Receivers also provide liquid injection, for oil cooling, to High Stage Compressors #8, #9, #10, and Booster Compressors #6 and #8.



High pressure liquid ammonia passing through the Intercooler is provided to the Blast Cell Recirculators (2), Freezer Accumulators (3), Sure Fresh Pump Package, Berry Cool Pump Package, and when needed, system 2.  Suction from these areas is drawn off by the Booster Compressors and Suction Accumulator/Slop Tank prior to entering the High Stage Compressors.  Booster Compressor discharge is routed to the Intercooler. Suction from the Poly Bag Room passes through the Suction Accumulator/Slop Tank prior to entering the High Stage Compressors.  After a predetermined amount of liquid has accumulated in the Suction Accumulator's Transfer Unit, the Transfer Unit opens the high pressure hot gas line, forcing the accumulated liquid out of the vessel and into the High Pressure Receivers.



System 1 has a total of 64 Evaporators/Coil Units and an IQF Freezer.  Fans in each Evaporator/Coil Unit are used to draw air across the coils which partially vaporizes the liquid ammonia as h

eat from the room is transferred to the ammonia within the coils.



The High Stage Compressors pull vapor from the above mentioned vessels (and system 2 when needed) and discharge through a common header to the Condensers where the gas is condensed to a high pressure liquid and then drained back to the High Pressure Receivers.  The high pressure vapor is condensed by discharging latent heat in the ammonia to the atmosphere using sprayed water and fans.  High Stage Compressor discharge is also used for the defrosting of the Poly Bag Room, Vestibule Area (Dock), Holding Rooms, Berry Cooler Pressure Coolers/Blowers, Berry Cooler, Freezer Room #3, and Blast Cell Evaporators/Coil Units.  



An auto purger periodically purges system 1 of non-condensibles collected in the Condensers.  Oil from system 1 is collected and drained via Engine Room #1's Oil Purge Tank.  System 1 is also equipped with an Under-Floor Heat Exchanger which is used for heating of the freezer area floors.



Refrigeration process equipment associated with system 2 does not operate continuously.  The system operates when cooling is needed at the Individual Quick Freeze (IQF) freezer.  The System 2 Compressors and Condenser cycle on and off to comply with system demand during operation.  System 2 provides cooling for the #8 IQF only.



System 2's refrigeration cycle begins with the collecting of high pressure liquid ammonia in the High Pressure Receivers (2) from the Condenser.  The High Pressure Receivers serve as the main liquid storage vessels for system 2.  The High Pressure Receivers provide high pressure liquid ammonia to Economizers/Subcoolers and liquid injection to Compressors #1, #3, #5, #7 and #8 .  The Economizers/Subcoolers provide subcooled liquid to the IQF Pump Package.  The IQF Pump Package pumps liquid to the IQF where the liquid vaporizes (hence providing cooling).  The vaporized suction is returned to the IQF Pump Package.  System 2's Compressors pull suction from the IQF Pump Pac

kage through the Accumulator/Slop Tank.  The Accumulator protects the Compressors from directly receiving liquid.  After a predetermined amount of liquid has accumulated in the Slop Tank/Accumulator, the vessel's pump returns the accumulated liquid to the #8 IQF Pump Package.



Suction from the Accumulator first passes through the Low Stage Compressors before its pressure is increased further by the High Stage Compressors. The High Stage Compressors discharge through a common header to the Condenser where the gas is condensed to a high pressure liquid and then drained back to the High Pressure Receivers.  Oil from system 2 is collected and drained via System 2's Oil Purge Tank.



Both system's pressure relief valves are replaced every five years and designed in accordance with "American National Standard for Equipment, Design, and Installation of Ammonia Mechanical Refrigeration Systems" sponsored by IIAR and approved by The American National Standards Institute.   





RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Sunrise Growers ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation, the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program and EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP).  Refrigeration contractors, experts in the ammonia refrigeration industry, are contracted at the facility to regularly maintain the system and perform any repairs.



Ammonia detectors are strategically located in the engine rooms and throughout the facility.  During the PHA Revalidation conducted on February 20-21, 2014, the facility was installing new  ammonia sensors.  In case of ammonia detection, an offsite monitoring station receives an alarm and then proceeds to alert the facility.  



In the event of a power failure, ammonia operations

would automatically shut-down (solenoid valves close, compressors shut-down, condenser fans and water pumps shut-down, evaporator fans shut-down, etc.), thereby limiting the possibility of any ammonia releases.



The system also incorporates pressure relief valves.  In the event of over-pressurization, vessels will vent to atmosphere via relief lines which penetrate through the roof.  This mechanism prevents vessels from rupturing in case they become over pressurized.



Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the systems are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar to a household refrigerator.  The refrigeration system is a closed-loop system without any regular emissions or releases.  Any leaks are noted and repaired immediately by the refrigeration contractor.



In addition to the 1997 Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines.  In particular, IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems" is used as a general guide.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The EPA's RMP Program defines "accident" as the following:



"An unanticipated emission of a regulated substance or other extremely hazardous substance into the ambient air from a stationary source."



The release must have caused at least one of the following:



?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (19CCR2750.9(a)); or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (19CCR2750.9(a))."



Based on the above definition and an investigation into the facility's accident history conducted at the time of the facility name change update(January 15, 2016), there have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of

100 pounds or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material in the last five years (February 2011 - February 2016). In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Sunrise Growers is subject to OSHA regulations at 29 CFR 1910.38 and State EPCRA Rules of Laws. They have an emergency action plan in effect at the facility.  The Emergency Action Plan is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP document. The Emergency Action Plan was last updated on August 20, 2007.  Emergency response activities are coordinated with the County of Santa Barbara Fire Department ((805) 681-5500) and the City of Santa Maria Fire Department (Fire Station #1 (805) 925-0951 Ext. 257).  In case of a major ammonia emergency, the facility will first call 9-1-1 to alert the local Police and Fire Departments.  Other responders will be called as needed, including the Department of Public Safety Emergency Management Services.  If a release exceeds the federal reporting quantity of 100 pounds for ammonia, the National Response Center and the Emergency Spill Report Center will be called.  The table below details the emergency notification list and contact phone numbers. All employees and contractors will evacuate based on a high ammonia leak alarm.



Sunrise Growers maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  The plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations,

as well as to incorporate any facility changes.



Sunrise Growers will be responsible for evacuating and ensuring the safety of its employees and will coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



A Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) Revalidation study was conducted on February 20-21, 2014.  The PHA Revalidation report includes the results from the following two elements: 1) the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study and 2) a Site Inspection. These studies were performed to define potential hazards associated with operational deviations of the ammonia system.  As a result of the Process Hazards Analysis, a number of recommendations were made, such as procedural changes, ammonia awareness training and some equipment upgrades.  These recommendations are scheduled to be completed by February 2015.



In addition, the facility is planning to complete several items over the next year to help with their continued effort to provide a safe work environment for Sunrise Growers employees.  These changes include the following items:



1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.



2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.



3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.



4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
